data.title: Burt at the Burt: Cummings comes home
data.meta_description: “If I said I were not nervous, I would be lying,” Burton Cummings claimed minutes into his latest homecoming show.
data.text:
Article content

“If I said I were not nervous, I would be lying,” Burton Cummings claimed minutes into his latest homecoming show.

He needn’t have worried. After all, the former Guess Who frontman pretty much owns this town. Around these parts, he’s a local hero. A living legend. A bona fide home-grown rock star. Not to mention the guy whose name adorns the very building he was playing.

In other words: In all the theatres in all the towns in all the world, Cummings couldn’t have found a more receptive audience than the one that welcomed him with open arms Wednesday night at (where else?) the Burton Cummings Theatre. The sold-out crowd of more than 1,500 adoring fans included everyone from twentysomething hipsters with a taste for the oldies to greybeards — some with canes, walkers and even scooters — taking a trip down memory lane.

Both sides got what they wanted as the 64-year-old singer-pianist led his crack backing through two hours of hits from his Guess Who years, his solo career and even his pre-fame days. All were delivered with enough energy, exuberance and exertion to make it clear this was a rock show — but also with enough personality and intimacy to remind you that it was, as Cummings said, a very special night.

Opening with his usual starter — the one-two punch of No Sugar Tonight / New Mother Nature — Cummings displayed none of the jitters to which he would soon lay claim. His long-serving quintet The Carpet Frogs eased into the song as Burton strode onstage, clad in his perennial ensemble of black jeans, unbuttoned black work shirt and, yes, black T-shirt (this one had a picture of a giant yellow 45 adapter on the front). Sitting at his electronic keyboard with his legs spread, he presented the Guess Who two-fer with all the skill and confidence you’d expect from a guy who’s been on the job for decades. He even rose to do a graceful little dance during the the instrumental bridge. If this was a nervous Burton, one wonders how he behaves when he’s relaxed.

A succession of classics followed — the rollicking Albert Flasher, complete with Jerry Lee Lewis-style right-hand work from Burton; the lightly funky Clap for the Wolfman; the slow-burning Guns, Guns, Guns; and the driving Running Back to Saskatoon, fittingly described by Cummings as “the first true Canadian rock song.” He stood to blow some harmonica on the latter, and by the time he sat back down, it was obvious he had already worked up a healthy sweat after barely 20 minutes onstage. Not bad for a guy who will officially be a senior citizen on Dec. 31.

Even more impressive: Cummings still has the musical chops to match that energy. His playing was solid and strong as ever, and as anyone who’s heard his recent Live at Massey Hall album can attest, he’s arguably a better singer now than back in the day. Sure, like most aging vocalists, he’s lost some of his upper register (“Cut me some hometown slack on the high notes,” he begged before These Eyes). But possibly as a result, he’s become more of a crooner, singing softly in his lower register instead of belting out everything at the top of his lungs. Case in point: Stand Tall, whose chorus sounds far more intimate and evocative now than the brittle, nasal version of old.

Speaking of crooners, at one point Cummings dismissed his band to play (believe it or not) Bobby Darin’s Mack the Knife, which he absolutely nailed (if this rock thing doesn’t work out, he’s ready for the piano bar). Then came another ballad for the community club crowd: A moody Blue is the Night, the first single from his pre-Guess Who outfit The Deverons. “I don’t usually do this, but I have to do it in Winnipeg,” he said quite rightly.

By this point, Cummings was obviously over his nerves. And the more he relaxed, the more he began to talk. And talk. “Since this is Winnipeg, I can explain a few things,” he said — and eventually spent much of the evening doing just that, reminiscing and rambling between virtually every song about the old days, old friends, old haunts and old bands. He spoke of seeing The Beatles movie Help! in the former Odeon Theatre. He remembered writing These Eyes with Randy Bachman while he was a teenager still living with his mother and grandmother in the North End (“The drinking age was 21. I had a gold record before I had a beer; made up for that in later years, though”). He praised Winnipeg as the city that equipped him for the fame that later came his way (“You only get one hometown, and this is mine”). He fondly recalled late bandmate Kurt Winter and an ill-conceived Atlantic cruise they took one December (“We followed the same route as the Titanic”). He related the plotline of a Kojak episode that inspired Break it to Them Gently (the song itself earned a standing ovation thanks to its extended outro, when Cummings quoted a plethora of classic-rock lyrics). He even repeated celebrity-roast jokes (“How much cocaine can Charlie Sheen snort? Enough to kill Two and a Half Men! Thank you! I’m here all week; it’s a two-drink minimum”). Sometimes his introductions lasted longer than the songs themselves. But even if it sometimes slowed the momentum of the show, nobody was complaining.

Thankfully, he also pointed out that ultimately, the night was about music. “We have no dancers … no pyrotechnics … no computers adding extra parts … And we aren’t exactly fashionistas,” he cracked. “So what do we have? We have a whole lot of songs, and we’re actually singing and playing them up here.” And his band did a fine job of it. Granted, it was the slick, professional grade of rock you get at a casino or a state fair, as opposed to the raw, unbridled power of an indie-rock show. But that didn’t stop them from pounding out the hard-hitting Hand Me Down World and the barnburner Star Baby. Nor did it soften the blow of American Woman. The Guess Who’s signature song began with an extended blues-jam prologue (with Cummings blowing harmonica, channeling Jim Morrison and singing infamously silly lines like “Whatcha gonna do mama, now that the roast beef's gone?”). Then, of course, it segued into the Zeppish power-chord rocker we all know and love, with Burton standing at the mic before bashing away on his drummer’s cymbals with a tambourine. He switched instruments one final time to close the main set, donning a guitar for a rendition of No Time that was slightly gentler and strummier than the old single — but still got the crowd to its feet and clapping along.

Returning for the encore, Cummings reiterated it hadn’t been the easiest night going in. “I was very nervous, but you made this a wonderful experience … it’s purely for fun now, folks.” To wit: He and the band cranked out a raucous but spot-on version of the frat-rock classic Louie Louie, followed by a superb closer in the hippie-rock anthem Share the Land.

If I said the proceedings were anything less than outstanding, I would be lying.

Set List:

No Sugar Tonight / New Mother Nature

Albert Flasher

Clap for the Wolfman

Guns, Guns, Guns

Running Back to Saskatoon

Stand Tall

Mack the Knife

Blue is the Night

My Own Way to Rock

I'm Scared

Hand Me Down World

Break it to Them Gently

Star Baby

These Eyes

American Woman

No Time

Encore:

Louie Louie

Share the Land
